posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: Hey guys, Quick question: Is there a way to get the robotâ€™s position relative to the April tag position. i.e -1 meter offset in the x axis, 3 meter offset in the y axis, 20 degree rotation offset from apriltag. Iâ€™m using wpilib java and limelight. Thanks!

posts.name: icemannie
posts.cooked: Get the tag pose from the april tag field layout and the robot pose from odometry and do some math.

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: @icemannie One thing Iâ€™m confused about is how is the April tag rotation returned by the April Tag field layout calculated? I can input the ID and get a angle back, for example 120 degrees, but from where is that angle measured from?

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked:
(Iâ€™m not a programmer and never have been; take what I say with a grain of salt)

Since you know where every April tag is on the field, you can program in what ordination every April is relative to the field (this strategy only works if your robot is field oriented). Once the limelight sees a particular April tag, the robot can rotate itself to be the same ordination as the April relative to the field.

Once again, I have no idea what Iâ€™m talking about. Hope this helps somehow

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: @Kully Thanks for writing that tutorial, Iâ€™ve read it already and it has been very helpful for developing my alignment code. However, I realized at longer distances, the bot pose relative to the tag struggled a lot with accuracy, thus I decided to shift to a field-oriented approach using the April tag position on the field from the AprilTagFieldLayout provided by WPILib, like @Lyinlyon suggested. I have been able to get the translational movement to work with a decent level of precision and accuracy, but our rotation alignment is completely screwed up right now. When our robot is facing directly in front the April tag, we expect the difference between the robot and tag position to be close to  0 degrees but instead it seems to return large angles like 110 or 130 degrees instead. I suspect this issue has to do with what our robot thinks is 0 degrees is different with what AprilTagFieldLayout thinks is 0 degrees, creating an offset between the robot and April tag position, but I canâ€™t seem to find anywhere describing how the rotational values on the AprilTagFieldLayout are measured.

That is amazing as i said in the tutorial the way i showed is the simplest and most basic and if you have the time and knowledge definitely improve and do it better

Now for your problem

Are you able to share the code and maybe a video showing the problem?

How are you getting the tag data? How are you getting the pose and rotation data?

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: Ok, sorry for the late reply. I ran some more testing and I ended up realizing that the problem wasnâ€™t with the April tag detection itself, but rather with the swerve driveâ€™s y axis odometry being inverted for some reason. Thanks for your help though, I really appreciate it!
